questions.question_text: You have been provided with three test tubes. One of them contains distilled water and the other two contain an acidic solution and a basic solution, respectively. If you are given only red litmus paper, how will you identify the contents of each test tube?
hints: Use red litmus paper to test for acidity or basicity

questions.question_text: Why should curd and sour substances not be kept in brass and copper vessels?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of curd and sour substances

questions.question_text: Which gas is usually liberated when an acid reacts with a metal? Illustrate with an example. How will you test for the presence of this gas?
hints: Consider the reaction between an acid and a metal

questions.question_text: Metal compound A reacts with dilute hydrochloric acid to produce effervescence. The gas evolved extinguishes a burning candle. Write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction if one of the compounds formed is calcium chloride.
hints: Consider the reaction between a metal compound and an acid

questions.question_text: Why do HCl, HNO3, etc., show acidic characters in aqueous solutions while solutions of compounds like alcohol and glucose do not show acidic character?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of HCl and HNO3

questions.question_text: Why does an aqueous solution of an acid conduct electricity?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of acids in aqueous solutions

questions.question_text: Why does dry HCl gas not change the colour of the dry litmus paper?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of HCl gas

questions.question_text: While diluting an acid, why is it recommended that the acid should be added to water and not water to the acid?
hints: Consider the safety precautions when handling acids

questions.question_text: How is the concentration of hydronium ions (H3O+) affected when a solution of an acid is diluted?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of acids in aqueous solutions

questions.question_text: How is the concentration of hydroxide ions (OH–) affected when excess base is dissolved in a solution of sodium hydroxide?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of bases in aqueous solutions

questions.question_text: You have two solutions, A and B. The pH of solution A is 6 and pH of solution B is 8. Which solution has more hydrogen ion concentration? Which of this is acidic and which one is basic?
hints: Consider the pH scale

questions.question_text: What effect does the concentration of H+(aq) ions have on the nature of the solution?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of acids in aqueous solutions

questions.question_text: Do basic solutions also have H+(aq) ions? If yes, then why are these basic?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of bases in aqueous solutions

questions.question_text: Under what soil condition do you think a farmer would treat the soil of his fields with quick lime (calcium oxide) or slaked lime (calcium hydroxide) or chalk (calcium carbonate)?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of soil

questions.question_text: What is the common name of the compound Ca(ClO)2?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of Ca(ClO)2

questions.question_text: Name the substance which on treatment with chlorine yields bleaching powder.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of bleaching powder

questions.question_text: Name the sodium compound which is used for softening hard water.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of sodium compounds

questions.question_text: What will happen if a solution of sodium hydrocarbonate is heated? Give the equation of the reaction involved.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of sodium hydrocarbonate

questions.question_text: Write an equation to show the reaction between Plaster of Paris and water.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of Plaster of Paris

questions.question_text: A solution turns red litmus blue, its pH is likely to be
hints: Consider the pH scale

questions.question_text: A solution reacts with crushed egg-shells to give a gas that turns lime-water milky. The solution contains
hints: Consider the chemical properties of the solution

questions.question_text: 10 mL of a solution of NaOH is found to be completely neutralised by 8 mL of a given solution of HCl. If we take 20 mL of the same solution of NaOH, the amount HCl solution (the same solution as before) required to neutralise it will be
hints: Consider the chemical properties of NaOH and HCl

questions.question_text: Which one of the following types of medicines is used for treating indigestion?
hints: Consider the medical uses of different types of medicines

questions.question_text: Write word equations and then balanced equations for the reaction taking place when – (a) dilute sulphuric acid reacts with zinc granules. (b) dilute hydrochloric acid reacts with magnesium ribbon. (c) dilute sulphuric acid reacts with aluminium powder. (d) dilute hydrochloric acid reacts with iron filings.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of the reactants

questions.question_text: Compounds such as alcohols and glucose also contain hydrogen but are not categorised as acids. Describe an Activity to prove it.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of alcohols and glucose

questions.question_text: Why does distilled water not conduct electricity, whereas rain water does?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of water

questions.question_text: Why do acids not show acidic behaviour in the absence of water?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of acids

questions.question_text: Five solutions A, B, C, D and E when tested with universal indicator showed pH as 4, 1, 11, 7 and 9, respectively. Which solution is (a) neutral? (b) strongly alkaline? (c) strongly acidic? (d) weakly acidic? (e) weakly alkaline? Arrange the pH in increasing order of hydrogen-ion concentration.
hints: Consider the pH scale

questions.question_text: Equal lengths of magnesium ribbons are taken in test tubes A and B. Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is added to test tube A, while acetic acid (CH3COOH) is added to test tube B. Amount and concentration taken for both the acids are same. In which test tube will the fizzing occur more vigorously and why?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of HCl and CH3COOH

questions.question_text: Fresh milk has a pH of 6. How do you think the pH will change as it turns into curd? Explain your answer.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of milk and curd

questions.question_text: A milkman adds a very small amount of baking soda to fresh milk. (a) Why does he shift the pH of the fresh milk from 6 to slightly alkaline? (b) Why does this milk take a long time to set as curd?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of baking soda and milk

questions.question_text: Plaster of Paris should be stored in a moisture-proof container. Explain why?
hints: Consider the chemical properties of Plaster of Paris

questions.question_text: What is a neutralisation reaction? Give two examples.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of acids and bases

questions.question_text: Give two important uses of washing soda and baking soda.
hints: Consider the chemical properties of washing soda and baking soda
